messages.text: Welcome to the Trace Your Thinking interview system. This platform is designed to capture your thoughts about urban zoning and housing development. Would you like me to guide you through using this system?
yes

You have two options for answering questions: voice recording or typing. For voice recording, press the microphone button (ðŸŽ¤) or the Space key to start recording. When finished, press the microphone button or Space key again to stop. You can also press ESC to cancel. The system will automatically transcribe and submit your response after recording. Would you like to try voice recording now?
I am working on the microphone set up.

For text input, click the message icon (ðŸ’¬) to switch modes. Type your response in the text box. Press Ctrl+Enter or click the send button (âž¤) to submit. You can press ESC to clear your text. Would you like to try text input now?
I cannot get it to record

You can switch between voice and text modes at any time. In voice mode, the microphone button will show as red when recording is active. During transcription, you'll see 'Transcribing your speech...' and your answer will be automatically submitted once ready. Feel comfortable with the system now?
Sort of

As the interview progresses, you'll notice the progress bar at the top of the screen showing your current position. Based on your responses, the system may generate follow-up questions to dive deeper into specific topics. These new questions will be added to your interview flow automatically. This helps us capture your thinking process more thoroughly.
Ok, sounds good
Excellent! We're now ready to begin the interview about urban zoning policies. Take your time with each response and provide as much detail as you'd like. Let's start with our first question.
ok
To what extent do you support or oppose upzoning policies that allow for higher density housing in traditionally single-family neighborhoods? Please explain your reasoning.

I think it will be problematic. Speaking only about the United States, most single-family neighborhoods aren't exactly the picture of inclusion. Add to that the current political climate and throwing in a change to their neighborhoods I think will be catastrophic.
What do you think are the most significant impacts, positive or negative, of increasing housing density in residential neighborhoods?

Well on the positive side it would increase and give variation to any housing shortages or crises.  Also, it would create diversity in the neighborhood. Negatively though I could see the traffic and an increase in the demand put on the city could become an issue if not properly considered.
How do you think upzoning policies might affect housing affordability in urban areas?
Depends on the area. I think it has the potential to both increase affordability or decrease it. Are these luxury units or just common apartments? Are we talking wealthier areas or low income?
What impact do you believe increased housing density might have on neighborhood character and quality of life?
I think it would provide more character and a way better quality of life. I love when different cultures collide and having more people means a more diverse environment.
How do you think upzoning might affect transportation systems and traffic congestion in cities?
I think it would put a strain on those systems in certain areas. I do not think this is a one size fits all type of idea. Not every city could accommodate this type of structure.
What role do you believe local government should play in regulating housing development and density?
The government should definitely play a role in making sure there is affordable housing for all. I think that pretty much encompasses any development needed in the best way possible.
How might environmental concerns factor into decisions about urban density and zoning?
Well, loss of land for starters. Then the strain on the water, sewage, trash, and other resources.
What economic effects, both positive and negative, might result from changing zoning laws to allow more multi-family housing?

I think there will be more positive effects than negative economically. Local businesses will see an increase in traffic, service industries will have more potential clients, the city will benefit by the increase in population, and so much more than I can think of. I don't see too much negative economically unless the city itself wasn't prepared for the influx in the population.
How do you think the interests of current residents versus future residents should be balanced when making zoning decisions?
The current residents should get some type of say or voting. Government always says to use our voices well then they have to be heard and actual action must happen.
What role do you think social equity and access to opportunity play in discussions about zoning and housing policy?
That's a good question. It should play a significant role. Fairness has to be considered or this is just a fancy way of saying "the projects"

Does Inclusion have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

I believe it has a positive effect. Inclusion has always been beneficial as the goal is to garner support for the up zoning. Inclusion increases the chances of that happening. I would say it has an extremely positive effect by increasing it.
What factors do you think influence Support for Upzoning, and how strong is their impact? Please also indicate if these influences are positive (increasing) or negative (decreasing).

I believe these factors decrease support for upzoning like concern for property values, societal rules around aesthetics, safety concerns, and city concerns. Positive factors I think might encourage more support would be diversity, inclusivity, cultural exchanges, and increased affordability.

Is the effect of Diversity on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
It really depends but it might take some time to develop. Rarely is anything immediate especially when we are talking people and change.

How confident are you that changes in Housing Affordability lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

I am not confident about it but it is my opinion that would cause me to support it. Whether I needed that affordability or not I would still want others to have a place to live that they could afford.

Is the effect of Neighborhood character on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
I also feel that this might take time to develop.I think that it might actually have a negative effect long term but initially I do think it will be positive.

Would small changes in Strain on transportation systems lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

I don't believe small changes would be that noticeable but that also depends on what city we are talking about. Where I live we do not use much public transportation expect in the 2 largest metro areas. Therefore, if you live in any surrounding suburb or rural area you have to have a car. In a larger city that heavily relies on public transportation it might be catastrophic but to a smaller city barely noticeable.

Is the effect of Affordable Housing on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

I would think this would be pretty quick because I think it would be the easiest way to convince the voters or others to give support to up zoning. I think it could be looked at from both ways but again any time housing is affordable that's a positive.

Is the effect of Strain on resources on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
I think this might take a little time to develop. Kind of like a ticking time bomb. I think it will definitely have a decently high negative effect.

How would you describe the relationship between Local businesses and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

I think there is a really strong connection between the local businesses and supporting up zoning. With the support of upzoning it eventually creating more customers is a positive effect for the local businesses.

How confident are you that changes in Current residents' input lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

The current residents are the voters and though they may not be heard their vote still counts. I think it could have a negative effect if the residents are forced into this without their support. I think it could have a strong negative effect on the support of the up zoning.
How confident are you that changes in Fairness lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

I am not confident because again fairness is something I think should happen because it is right and I recently watched a local really wealthy city in my home state veto affordable housing because of all the hard work it took to get them there. They didn't want to lose their values. So, I don't believe fairness will garner much support of up zoning.
What factors do you think influence Single-family neighborhoods, and how strong is their impact? Please also indicate if these influences are positive (increasing) or negative (decreasing).
Well, the same factors that plague most families is schools, safety, and proximity to available services, amenities, and necessities.

Is the effect of Time required for development on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
I would think it is not immediate and that it would have a negative effect on support. Too much time creates disinterest.

Is the effect of Time required for development on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

qaPairs.answer: I would think this would be pretty quick because I think it would be the easiest way to convince the voters or others to give support to up zoning. I think it could be looked at from both ways but again any time housing is affordable that's a positive.

qaPairs.shortText: Relationship: Affordable Housing â†’ Support for Upzoning

qaPairs.answer: I think this might take a little time to develop. Kind of like a ticking time bomb. I think it will definitely have a decently high negative effect.
qaPairs.question: Is the effect of Strain on resources on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
qaPairs.shortText: Relationship: Strain on resources â†’ Support for Upzoning

qaPairs.answer: I think there is a really strong connection between the local businesses and supporting up zoning. With the support of upzoning it eventually creating more customers is a positive effect for the local businesses.

qaPairs.shortText: Relationship: Local businesses â†’ Support for Upzoning

qaPairs.answer: The current residents are the voters and though they may not be heard their vote still counts. I think it could have a negative effect if the residents are forced into this without their support. I think it could have a strong negative effect on the support of the up zoning.
qaPairs.question: How confident are you that changes in Current residents' input lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
qaPairs.shortText: Relationship: Current residents' input â†’ Support for Upzoning

qaPairs.answer: I am not confident because again fairness is something I think should happen because it is right and I recently watched a local really wealthy city in my home state veto affordable housing because of all the hard work it took to get them there. They didn't want to lose their values. So, I don't believe fairness will garner much support of up zoning.

qaPairs.answer: Well, the same factors that plague most families is schools, safety, and proximity to available services, amenities, and necessities.

messages.text: Welcome to the Trace Your Thinking interview system. This platform is designed to capture your thoughts about urban zoning and housing development. Would you like me to guide you through using this system?
you

You have two options for answering questions: voice recording or typing. For voice recording, press the microphone button (ðŸŽ¤) or the Space key to start recording. When finished, press the microphone button or Space key again to stop. You can also press ESC to cancel. The system will automatically transcribe and submit your response after recording. Would you like to try voice recording now?
you

For text input, click the message icon (ðŸ’¬) to switch modes. Type your response in the text box. Press Ctrl+Enter or click the send button (âž¤) to submit. You can press ESC to clear your text. Would you like to try text input now?
you

You can switch between voice and text modes at any time. In voice mode, the microphone button will show as red when recording is active. During transcription, you'll see 'Transcribing your speech...' and your answer will be automatically submitted once ready. Feel comfortable with the system now?
Yes, I am comfortable trying the system.

As the interview progresses, you'll notice the progress bar at the top of the screen showing your current position. Based on your responses, the system may generate follow-up questions to dive deeper into specific topics. These new questions will be added to your interview flow automatically. This helps us capture your thinking process more thoroughly.
That sounds great.
Excellent! We're now ready to begin the interview about urban zoning policies. Take your time with each response and provide as much detail as you'd like. Let's start with our first question.
Okay, I'm ready.
To what extent do you support or oppose upzoning policies that allow for higher density housing in traditionally single-family neighborhoods? Please explain your reasoning.

For the most part, I support upzoning policies. I came from Southern California, which did not have enough housing and the prices were through the roof. Our current town has a lot of open space, so I could see upzoning to create tall apartment buildings being a great solution to provide lower income and middle class families opportunities to purchase or live in nicer neighborhoods.
What do you think are the most significant impacts, positive or negative, of increasing housing density in residential neighborhoods?
I think.
How do you think upzoning policies might affect housing affordability in urban areas?

I think the most significant impact would be traffic and bringing house prices down. I think that upzoning policies would definitely affect the affordability in the area I live, which is more suburban.
What impact do you believe increased housing density might have on neighborhood character and quality of life?

Currently, the neighborhood I live in is mainly single family homes, but three blocks away they put in four story apartments and it changed the look a little bit, but you could tell the developer tried to keep it the same style, but only traffic and an additional stop sign is the difference I can see in the quality of life.
How do you think upzoning might affect transportation systems and traffic congestion in cities?

When I first moved to this neighborhood, we didn't have as many stoplights and stop signs. And now that the apartment building and the new school is up and running, that would be an area in the transportation system that I've noticed. I don't think it has more congestion because it is running smoother now with the addition of the stoplight.
What role do you believe local government should play in regulating housing development and density?

I think local government plays a huge role in the development. I think that they are on top of the pulse of how many people in town are without homes and need more lower income and middle income opportunities.
How might environmental concerns factor into decisions about urban density and zoning?

I think environmental concerns are a big factor. Our neighborhood, for example, has cows that were dispersed when this neighborhood was built. We have a once a year grasshopper explosion that happens because nature is trying to find its way back to where we were.
What economic effects, both positive and negative, might result from changing zoning laws to allow more multi-family housing?

The economic effects from changing zoning laws to allow for multifamily housing definitely has positives and negatives. I think the positive is it brings a more diverse culture to your neighborhood. Negative is some people might think their home values might go down, but in this current market where housing is through the roof, I think we could do for a little settling of how expensive housing prices are.
How do you think the interests of current residents versus future residents should be balanced when making zoning decisions?

I think the interests of the current residents have already been taken into account. If you buy a house and you have a mortgage, I don't necessarily think your interests are as important as people who can't afford to buy a house. I think the people who need homes and need to find housing that is safe and appropriate for their children needs to be more important than the current interests of the residents that already have homes.
What role do you think social equity and access to opportunity play in discussions about zoning and housing policy?

I think this is hugely important. Social equity and access to housing is so important. There are too many people that are pushed out of the housing market because the prices are too high and the interest rates have skyrocketed. I think that the discussions need to be centered around how can we make sure anyone who wants to buy a house can buy a house or an apartment.

How confident are you that changes in High housing prices lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

My confidence level is medium. I think having a upzoning is an option for creating some change, but I think more change needs to happen. And it can't just happen in lower and middle class neighborhoods. It needs to be happening in all neighborhoods or else it feels unbalanced. Because there is positive effects, but there's also negative effects. Because like mentioned before, you have more traffic and more resources being used.
What factors do you think influence Support for Upzoning, and how strong is their impact? Please also indicate if these influences are positive (increasing) or negative (decreasing).

I think the factors that support upzoning are people who want to get into the market, who want their kids to go to good schools. So if there's opportunities with condos or apartment buildings that are building up, that creates a positive change because everyone deserves to send their kids to a good school.

Is the effect of House prices on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
I think it takes time to develop. I know in our neighborhood when the apartments went up there was some concern, but I think that overall the positive effect supersedes any negative effects.

How confident are you that changes in Four-story apartments lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

I'm semi-confident that for a four-story apartment would lead to changes and support for upzoning. I think the support is coming from outside the area, not necessarily current residents. I think it has positive effect because it brings people into your neighborhood that might not necessarily be able to afford it. And there is the negative effect of traffic and congestion and resources being used. And the effect is going to be strong on both sides.

How would you describe the relationship between Transportation Systems and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

In an ideal world, the local government would make sure the relationship between transportation systems and support for upzoning would work together. Like I mentioned earlier, when our three or four story apartments went up around the corner, we had to have a new stop sign put in, we needed a new stoplight to be put in, because there was more traffic.

Is the effect of Neighborhood Development on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

I think the effect of neighborhood development for supporting the upzoning took quite a while to develop. I don't think it was immediate. I think current homeowners probably saw it as a negative and the question of how strong is this effect is pretty strong. People were very concerned.

Would small changes in Housing development lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

I think small changes are great, but big changes make a bigger difference. If you're going to support upzoning, you need to be able to support it with more schools, more grocery stores, more gas stations. So small changes seems like it moves too slowly. For that positive effect to increase, you need to see the changes moving a little faster and bigger.

Is the effect of Urban density on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

I think the urban density support for upzoning is over time to develop the support. I think that there is both positive effects and negative effects. For example, we just got our first gas station on this side of town and that's a positive effect, but waiting for it was negative.

How would you describe the relationship between Diverse Culture and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

I think there is a relationship between diverse culture and support for upzoning. I think that it's important for people to recognize that that connection is strong and we need to recognize that not everyone is going to look the same or have the same economic, socioeconomic similarities, that our differences are what bring us together and the effect of that is very strong.

How would you describe the relationship between Future residents' needs and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

How would I describe the relationship between future residents' needs and support for upzoning? I think the connection is strong there. I think when you consider future residents, they're going to need the infrastructure, be able to driving back and forth. I think you're going to need schools for families and that support for upzoning is going to come in because people who want to live in certain neighborhoods are going to support upzoning. I think the connection is strong. I think it would have a positive effect because when you bring families into neighborhoods, that's a positive effect.

Would small changes in Affordability of housing lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

I don't believe that small changes in affordability of housing would lead to noticeable changes in support for upzoning. I think that the current housing market is out of reach for a large population of people. Even the middle class can't get into the housing market. So it requires these larger shifts. And does it have a positive or negative effect? Well, I think it all depends on the changes. Is it a small affordability of housing change or a large?

Does Social Equity have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

I think in this day and age, in 2025, social equity needs to have a positive effect that all of us should be supporting upzoning so that all people, families, individuals who want to be able to live in certain areas, that the local government will make it possible. I think this would have a positive effect and I think it would be strong.

Does Access to Opportunity have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

Does access to opportunity have a positive or negative effect for support for upzoning? I believe it has a positive effect. And I think it's significant because the effect being positive is strong when you think about wanting to support people getting into housing.
What causes changes in Housing shortage? Are these influences strong or weak?

The changes in housing shortage is both strong and weak. In a very expensive area, it is hugely a strong influence on people's lives because if you can't find housing you can afford, you're put in positions that you shouldn't be in. Everyone should be able to find housing that's within their cost of living.

Does Good schools have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

I think good schools have a very positive effect on the support for upzoning. When you see a school with great scores and a reputation and there's land near it, it's only natural for people to want to have more housing in that area so families can send their kids there. I think it's a very strong effect.

Would small changes in Condos or apartment buildings lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

I think small changes in condos or apartment buildings would lead to noticeable changes in support for upzoning. It's very rare that condos and apartment buildings are built in towns that are more residential like the suburbs. So I think it would have a positive effect and I do think it would be strong.

Would small changes in Condos or apartment buildings lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

messages.text: Welcome to the Trace Your Thinking interview system. This platform is designed to capture your thoughts about urban zoning and housing development. Would you like me to guide you through using this system?
you

You have two options for answering questions: voice recording or typing. For voice recording, press the microphone button (ðŸŽ¤) or the Space key to start recording. When finished, press the microphone button or Space key again to stop. You can also press ESC to cancel. The system will automatically transcribe and submit your response after recording. Would you like to try voice recording now?

For text input, click the message icon (ðŸ’¬) to switch modes. Type your response in the text box. Press Ctrl+Enter or click the send button (âž¤) to submit. You can press ESC to clear your text. Would you like to try text input now?
test

You can switch between voice and text modes at any time. In voice mode, the microphone button will show as red when recording is active. During transcription, you'll see 'Transcribing your speech...' and your answer will be automatically submitted once ready. Feel comfortable with the system now?
yes

As the interview progresses, you'll notice the progress bar at the top of the screen showing your current position. Based on your responses, the system may generate follow-up questions to dive deeper into specific topics. These new questions will be added to your interview flow automatically. This helps us capture your thinking process more thoroughly.
okay
Excellent! We're now ready to begin the interview about urban zoning policies. Take your time with each response and provide as much detail as you'd like. Let's start with our first question.
let's start
To what extent do you support or oppose upzoning policies that allow for higher density housing in traditionally single-family neighborhoods? Please explain your reasoning.

I am not a fan of these new upzoning policies because it is going to result in middle class and working class homes losing value, open the door to more crime, and these same types of buildings are not being built in rich areas so I see it as a form of class warfare.
What do you think are the most significant impacts, positive or negative, of increasing housing density in residential neighborhoods?

I think the biggest impact will be the reduction in value of the surrounding single family homes. New upzoning should be limited to specific areas where they will not be disruptive to the local economy.
How do you think upzoning policies might affect housing affordability in urban areas?
I think the housing prices will go down because the value of the single homes will go down
What impact do you believe increased housing density might have on neighborhood character and quality of life?

The neighborhood's quality will significantly decrease because views will be blocked and too many people will be suddenly arriving in small areas that previously were not built to handle this number of residents.
How do you think upzoning might affect transportation systems and traffic congestion in cities?
They will almost certainly become worse as the population increases but the transportation infrastructure remains the same.
What role do you believe local government should play in regulating housing development and density?

Housing deployment and density should be regulated to the extent that neighborhoods are protected and these new buildings are limited to newly developed areas rather than being placed in existing neighborhoods.
How might environmental concerns factor into decisions about urban density and zoning?
Certainly higher population will bring higher pollution
What economic effects, both positive and negative, might result from changing zoning laws to allow more multi-family housing?
I think it could allow for growth in the total number of people which could help some local businesses but it will also bring a series of problems that come with low income housing.
How do you think the interests of current residents versus future residents should be balanced when making zoning decisions?
I think the current residents should be given priority and allowed to vote on these zoning decisions.
What role do you think social equity and access to opportunity play in discussions about zoning and housing policy?
They should be considered but not the deciding factor.

Is the effect of Middle class homes losing value on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
This effect will likely happen almost immediately and will have a strongly negative effect.
What causes changes in Support for Upzoning? Are these influences strong or weak?
I think how people are affected is what determines the amount of support. The worse people are affected the stronger the resistance will be.

How would you describe the relationship between Reduction in value of single-family homes and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
I think it is a negative effect when you are decreasing the value of the existing homes in the area and forcing it on people will only galvanize them against the idea.

Would small changes in Decrease in home values lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
I think even small changes in home values will lead to strong resistance against upzoning because people are already living with razor thin margins.

How would you describe the relationship between Blocked views and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
The more views are blocked the more people will dislike upzoning. It is a strong connection.

Is the effect of Population increase on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
The effect will be almost immediate in my opinion and it will have a strong negative effect as more people become affected.

Is the effect of Limiting new buildings in existing neighborhoods on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
The limiting of new buildings in existing neighborhoods would obviously not have a fast effect because nothing is changing but when things do change the effect will become stronger.

Does Pollution have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
Pollution will increase with the population so cramming more people into a small area will definitely strongly increase pollution and people know this.

Does Impact on local businesses have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

I think sudden increase in population will make it harder to get jobs as positions become filled and economic conditions will become more strongly effected the higher the population or upzoning becomes.

How confident are you that changes in Voting rights in zoning decisions lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
I don't think changes in voting rights will effect support for upzoning because most people will be voting against it happening where they live.

How would you describe the relationship between Zoning Policy and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
Zoning policy and support for upzoning are probably inversely related and likely to have a strongly negative effect as the drawbacks become apparent to the voting population.

How confident are you that changes in Negative Effect lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
Definitely a negative effect, if something brings negative consequences then people are going to not like it and support will be reduced as the negative effects become more apparent over time.

Does People's perception of impact have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

People's perception have an effect on their support just as much as the reality. If they perceive something to be a harm to their prosperity or their livelihood then it is just the same as whether it were a perception or the reality because what matters is how an individual perceives the reality.

How would you describe the relationship between Strength of resistance and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
The strength of resistance will rise in equal amount to the support for upzoning depending on how people feel about it.
What factors affect Upzoning policies, and which ones have the strongest influence? Please also indicate if these influences are positive (increasing) or negative (decreasing).
The way people's home prices are effected, whether crime goes up, whether local jobs become harder to get, all of these things are likely to have a negative effect on support for upzoning.

How would you describe the relationship between Resistance against upzoning and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
It is a strong connection in the sense that it is inverse, as resistance grows, support weakens and vice versa.

How would you describe the relationship between Resistance against upzoning and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

Excellent! We're now ready to begin the interview about urban zoning policies. Take your time with each response and provide as much detail as you'd like. Let's start with our first question.
Okay.
To what extent do you support or oppose upzoning policies that allow for higher density housing in traditionally single-family neighborhoods? Please explain your reasoning.
It depends because I feel like if there's more housing it would bring prosperity for people's businesses, however it would also become overcrowded and it would be really hard to find parking.
What do you think are the most significant impacts, positive or negative, of increasing housing density in residential neighborhoods?

honestly I think it's very positive to have and build houses because a lot of people are in need and people are really looking for houses right now because there's a crisis going on. I think the negative would be overcrowded, very noisy, too much complaints and there would be just too much people walking, harder to get parking. Yeah.
How do you think upzoning policies might affect housing affordability in urban areas?
I think it would be very good because if there's more houses, there would be more people having options to rent it and they would not have to be homeless.
What impact do you believe increased housing density might have on neighborhood character and quality of life?

I have a playground right next to my house, like a little park. I think the park would become very busy. I think one positive would be people would be able to make new friends and they'd be able to hang out with new people. One of the positives, which I think is very important for young people. That's about it. I think I'd be able to make new friends and meet different kinds of people and share different cultures together.
How do you think upzoning might affect transportation systems and traffic congestion in cities?

As I said before, with parking, it would be really hard to find parking if it's overcrowded. For trains, I feel like it would be very crowded inside. People would not be able to get a seat and people would push each other to get inside the train. That might become a hazard.
What role do you believe local government should play in regulating housing development and density?
I think the government should see how much space it has and how many people live there and then build the houses so that it's all equally done and it's not overpopulated.
How might environmental concerns factor into decisions about urban density and zoning?

Environmental issues would be that it would become very polluted, there's going to be a lot of pollution, there's a lot of people that people would not recycle things, and there's not people following the rules, and yeah, there'd be a lot of pollution.
What economic effects, both positive and negative, might result from changing zoning laws to allow more multi-family housing?
economic effects would be that for businesses it would flourish it would be very good and yeah one of them there's a lot of houses that means the rent price would go down which is good for the public
How do you think the interests of current residents versus future residents should be balanced when making zoning decisions?
I think they should see what the current residents want from the future residents and they would see what they need instead of forcing it upon them and make a decision.
What role do you think social equity and access to opportunity play in discussions about zoning and housing policy?

I think if the houses were being put in a very sociable place, I think that would bring more opportunity to people. If there's a lot of people, there's a lot of ideas going on, then that means people would be able to have opportunities and people would build things, they would get their ideas and put it into action.

Is the effect of Overcrowding concerns on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

I think it would happen over time. It wouldn't just happen, it would happen over time and when it does happen over time, it does have negative effects such as parking as I said before, transportation, pollution, and people not following the rules, crimes increasing. The positives would be the economic status, like not economic status, the economy would benefit from how the businesses are getting people to buy products from them. The effect would be really bad if there's a lot of people, there's people that are good and bad in an area, so that means there would be an increased amount of crimes happening.

What do you think are the main causes of Support for Upzoning, and how certain are you about these relationships? Please also indicate if these influences are positive (increasing) or negative (decreasing).
People support these because they cannot afford to have housing and they want to have more options to have housing and for cheap. Yeah.

Does Positive impact have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

It has a positive effect on the people that are getting the option to get housing and get the rent for low, but it does have a negative effect on the people that are already living there to have more people coming and they don't know what type of people they are. And it could be very strong in a way that they don't share the same culture or they don't share the same opinions.

Does Increased housing supply have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

I would say negative, because a lot of people are coming in, they don't know what type of people are coming in, and if the people are threatening them, or if the characteristic of the neighborhood changes, the housing prices are getting affected, there's congestion, and yeah.

Would small changes in Playground/park activity lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

Playground and park activities could be seen to have a positive effect, and if it becomes a bigger playground, then more people would come to have fun, and the kids would be able to connect with their peers more, and they'd be able to have fun more, and which helps with their growth, and this is a way for the community to connect with each other as well.

How confident are you that changes in Parking availability lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

I would not say I'm very, very confident, I would say I'm in the middle, because if the city is very car dependent, it would make it very hard to find parking, and in areas where parking is very hard to find, people would not want other people coming in and making it hard for them, and it becomes also very hard for even homeowners who do not have parking, they have to park outside, they would not want other people to come in there.

Does Balanced population distribution have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

I would say it would be positive but if like the population growth is being distributed evenly then that means their neighborhood is being taken accounted for how many people should live there what the people should live there or like it's not overcrowded there should be a balance so if it's balanced then people will not complain

How would you describe the relationship between Pollution and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

I would say it's very strong because if it's a small group of people, it's very easy to follow rules and tell someone else like, oh you should not do that, everybody else is supporting, but if it's a very group of people, and there's a like few that are not following the rules, it's really hard to say like stop doing that because it's not just one person that's doing it, it's now a lot of people that's doing it. So they are not following the rules. So like plastics, they're not throwing it in the trash, or they're smoking, what they're not supposed to do. So pollution becomes very high, which is very bad for the community, the neighborhood, and the world. And the effect is very strong.

How confident are you that changes in Economic Effects lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

I think people who does have businesses they know that if more people come in their business would flourish and that they would get more people to buy them they would get more money so they would support like changes in their community they would support upzoning but people who do not have businesses or anything they would not support it so everybody who everybody wants money so if they see that they're gonna have an economic gain then they would want to do whatever it takes to get the gain

How would you describe the relationship between Business Flourishing and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

It is a very strong relationship between them because as I said if someone is owning a business And they know that they're gonna get more customers That means they will want more people coming to them. If they want more people coming to them They would want to upsell so the more people can come and buy from there and so that they get more money The effect is very strong

Would small changes in Collaborative decision-making lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

I think it would make a difference but not as much if people, like let's say if a group, a whole group of people says no and other people start to agree with them then it would just change to no if a lot of people says yes but some people are saying no but it would just stay yes so it depends on the amount of people who are expressing their emotions or who are expressing their opinions

Would small changes in Density and Interaction lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
Yes, it would because I feel like if it's a population or if it's a neighborhood where it's already overcrowded they would not support it.

Would small changes in Negative effects lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
That would definitely change people's viewpoint, they would not support it, since if negative effects increase, such as traffic, congestion, and noise complaints, then they would not support it.
What factors affect Prosperity through increased housing, and which ones have the strongest influence? Please also indicate if these influences are positive (increasing) or negative (decreasing).

messages.text: Welcome to the Trace Your Thinking interview system. This platform is designed to capture your thoughts about urban zoning and housing development. Would you like me to guide you through using this system?
Yes, please.

You have two options for answering questions: voice recording or typing. For voice recording, press the microphone button (ðŸŽ¤) or the Space key to start recording. When finished, press the microphone button or Space key again to stop. You can also press ESC to cancel. The system will automatically transcribe and submit your response after recording. Would you like to try voice recording now?
I want to type.

For text input, click the message icon (ðŸ’¬) to switch modes. Type your response in the text box. Press Ctrl+Enter or click the send button (âž¤) to submit. You can press ESC to clear your text. Would you like to try text input now?
Yes.

You can switch between voice and text modes at any time. In voice mode, the microphone button will show as red when recording is active. During transcription, you'll see 'Transcribing your speech...' and your answer will be automatically submitted once ready. Feel comfortable with the system now?
Yes.

As the interview progresses, you'll notice the progress bar at the top of the screen showing your current position. Based on your responses, the system may generate follow-up questions to dive deeper into specific topics. These new questions will be added to your interview flow automatically. This helps us capture your thinking process more thoroughly.
Okay, understood.
Excellent! We're now ready to begin the interview about urban zoning policies. Take your time with each response and provide as much detail as you'd like. Let's start with our first question.
Okay.
To what extent do you support or oppose upzoning policies that allow for higher density housing in traditionally single-family neighborhoods? Please explain your reasoning.
I support them practically entirely, because more housing is important for people who need it.
What do you think are the most significant impacts, positive or negative, of increasing housing density in residential neighborhoods?
Positive impacts are that people can find homes more easily. Negative impacts might be that there will be overcrowding.
How do you think upzoning policies might affect housing affordability in urban areas?
They would make housing a lot more affordable, because the more housing there is, the less they will be due to more availability.
What impact do you believe increased housing density might have on neighborhood character and quality of life?

Neighborhood character would increase positively because people will feel welcomed into the community. Quality of life might be more hectic in terms of travel, but people will still be able to easily manage.
How do you think upzoning might affect transportation systems and traffic congestion in cities?
There will definitely be an increase in traffic, but I am sure there can be policies to ease that burden and make things run as smoothly as possible.
What role do you believe local government should play in regulating housing development and density?
They should help to fund it through a surplus. If not, they should explain to the general public why they should support housing developments.
How might environmental concerns factor into decisions about urban density and zoning?
There would be a concern that climates can be negatively impacted due to carbon emissions going up, but emissions taxes could force people to do the right thing.
What economic effects, both positive and negative, might result from changing zoning laws to allow more multi-family housing?

There will be a better economy due to a large flow of money coming in from extra residents. Negative impacts on the economy will be practically non-existent, unless there are stock shortages due to overpopulation.
How do you think the interests of current residents versus future residents should be balanced when making zoning decisions?
They should both be taken into consideration equally, as no one resident matters more than another one.
What role do you think social equity and access to opportunity play in discussions about zoning and housing policy?
They play huge roles, because it is important to have equity so that all people can feel welcome.

Does Higher density housing have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
A pretty significant positive effect.

Would small changes in Housing availability lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
I think it is in proportion to the amount of changes.

Does Negative impact: Overcrowding have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
Negative. It has a huge negative impact because people do not like to feel overcrowded.
What causes changes in Support for Upzoning? Are these influences strong or weak?
Things like overcrowding, environmental concerns, and pricing changes play major roles. They can all be strong influences.

Does Housing affordability have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
Strong positive effect. The more housing affordability there is, the more support there will be, as people like affordable things.

Would small changes in Increased housing supply lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
There would need to be larger shifts. Small changes would only show small changes in support.

Does Positive neighborhood character have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
It has a major positive effect. If a neighborhood has a strong reputation, then there will be support for upzoning.

Would small changes in Policies to ease traffic burden lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
Even small changes would increase support significantly, because no one likes traffic.

Does Funding Housing Development have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
It has a  large positive effect, as being funded would mean that most people would not be taxed just to pay for it.

Does Environmental concerns have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
If people are concerned about the environment, then they will be significantly less likely to support this, because they would feel it brings a negative impact.

Does Carbon emissions have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
Carbon emissions have a very negative effect. This is because no one wants bad things for the environment.

Is the effect of Improved economy on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
It takes years to develop, as the economy fluctuates a lot, so they would need a larger sample size of economic performance.

Does Balanced decision-making have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
It has a large positive effect, because seeing balance in decision making would make people trusting,

How confident are you that changes in Inclusivity lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
Very confident, because inclusivity shows that everyone is welcome, which would lead to vastly more support overall.
What factors do you think influence Housing availability, and how strong is their impact? Please also indicate if these influences are positive (increasing) or negative (decreasing).
The economy, the environment, and potential taxes used to pay for it. These effects are all strong and crucial.

Does Overcrowding have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
Extremely negative, because people will feel like overcrowding will negatively impact their quality of life, as well as mobility.

Does Overcrowding have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

messages.text: Welcome to the Trace Your Thinking interview system. This platform is designed to capture your thoughts about urban zoning and housing development. Would you like me to guide you through using this system?
Yes, please.

You have two options for answering questions: voice recording or typing. For voice recording, press the microphone button (ðŸŽ¤) or the Space key to start recording. When finished, press the microphone button or Space key again to stop. You can also press ESC to cancel. The system will automatically transcribe and submit your response after recording. Would you like to try voice recording now?
Yes, let's begin.

For text input, click the message icon (ðŸ’¬) to switch modes. Type your response in the text box. Press Ctrl+Enter or click the send button (âž¤) to submit. You can press ESC to clear your text. Would you like to try text input now?
This works too

You can switch between voice and text modes at any time. In voice mode, the microphone button will show as red when recording is active. During transcription, you'll see 'Transcribing your speech...' and your answer will be automatically submitted once ready. Feel comfortable with the system now?
yes

As the interview progresses, you'll notice the progress bar at the top of the screen showing your current position. Based on your responses, the system may generate follow-up questions to dive deeper into specific topics. These new questions will be added to your interview flow automatically. This helps us capture your thinking process more thoroughly.
pk
Excellent! We're now ready to begin the interview about urban zoning policies. Take your time with each response and provide as much detail as you'd like. Let's start with our first question.
ok
To what extent do you support or oppose upzoning policies that allow for higher density housing in traditionally single-family neighborhoods? Please explain your reasoning.

I don't feel it's necessary.  Let's clean up old run down neighborhoods.  Let's redo those houses.  Population is down.  Why is there a need for apartment buildings?  We can go into poorer neighborhoods and refresh those houses.  There's lots of abandoned houses .  Let's clean that up.  No need for more apartments
What do you think are the most significant impacts, positive or negative, of increasing housing density in residential neighborhoods?
What is the need for it?  Population is down
How do you think upzoning policies might affect housing affordability in urban areas?
I'm not sure
What impact do you believe increased housing density might have on neighborhood character and quality of life?
We pay for our houses.  We don't want the value to go down for apartments when there are many other alternatives
How do you think upzoning might affect transportation systems and traffic congestion in cities?
make it worse
What role do you believe local government should play in regulating housing development and density?
None.  People shouldn't allow it
How might environmental concerns factor into decisions about urban density and zoning?
I don't know
What economic effects, both positive and negative, might result from changing zoning laws to allow more multi-family housing?

negative-houses lose value
positive-none
How do you think the interests of current residents versus future residents should be balanced when making zoning decisions?
Only current residents should have a voice
What role do you think social equity and access to opportunity play in discussions about zoning and housing policy?
I don't think that's important to be honest.  Fix up old neighborhoods.  Again, population is down.  Needs for apartments are down

Would small changes in Need for more apartments lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
Do you read how I respond?  We don't need apartments.  No small or large changes need to be made.  The answer will remain the same.  We don't need apartments
What causes changes in Support for Upzoning? Are these influences strong or weak?
Nothing causes changes in support for upzoning.  We don't need it

Does Need for increased housing density have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
We don't need increased housing density unless you're making smart cities which is not good

Would small changes in Property Value lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
It would lead to less support

How confident are you that changes in Traffic congestion lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
It wouldn't lead to support.  It would have a negative effect

How confident are you that changes in Individual autonomy lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
A very strong negative effect

How would you describe the relationship between Houses losing value and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
It's a strong negative connection

Does Zoning decisions have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
negative effect.  no support

How would you describe the relationship between Belief in necessity of apartments and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
weak connection. we don't need extra housing

Would small changes in Negative perception of smart cities lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
No changes would make a difference.  We don't want smart cities

How would you describe the relationship between Decrease in Support and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
